So here's the thing: I thought this season would be a total flop. I wasn't really that into Tokyo Ghoul before this season came out, anyway... Or so I thought.
If you're hoping to see characters from the first two seasons in Tokyo Ghoul:re, then you won't be disappointed. If you're hoping to see those characters a lot... Well, at least they're in there somewhat. The thing about this third season in the Tokyo Ghoul franchise is that it sets up a hell of a fourth season, and that alone makes it worth a watch. 
Naturally, the art and sound are stunning, as well as thebattles. However, the fact that Kaneki can't remember who he is makes for a very frustrating watchthrough. Don't get me wrong, the conflict inside of him is very interesting, especially when he begins learning about his past, and the new characters we meet this season are great as well, but... why mess with a good thing, you know? \n\n
But as I said, this season seems to be a sort of filler for the next season's plot. Which is fine, as long as I don't have to wait forever to see it. \n\n
All in all, not a bad revamp to the series. Hopefully the momentum picks up next season, because I have a feeling it's gonna be one hell of a show.

This season of Tokyo Ghoul is without a doubt the best adaptation of the entire franchise thus far. Although it will likely cover 58 chapters in this season, it is handling itself very well. The reason for this is that it's modifying its pacing so that it's slower when it needs to be and faster when it can be. Although this is by no means a perfect adaptation, it is still the best to date.
Story:
8/10
In terms of story, Tokyo Ghoul:re may not be nearly as thought-provoking as the original story, but it still does very well. Many people may be confused at the start ofthe series as to what the hell happened at the end of season 2. However, as time passes, that will all be revealed. They have also additionally retconned a couple of things that had been previously established within season 2 of the anime. As such, it may be a little difficult for anime only's to understand. It still does a great job nonetheless (especially in comparison to √A). In the end, however, what exactly happens in the season isn't nearly as important as the direction it takes the protagonist in. What people don't understand, however, is that Kaneki doesn't have amnesia. He forced himself to forget his past and that resulted in another personality.


Art:

9/10


The art style in Tokyo Ghoul:re takes itself in a very different direction than was previously seen but I think it works pretty well. It's pretty stylish but may not be everyone's cup of tea. The animation has become a little bit sloppy but that's not really what makes the series for the better or for the worse. It's not terrible but not the best.


Sound:

9/10


To be honest, in spite of how even Tokyo Ghoul √A did a good job with OST. However, :re finds a way to bring out some emotional and hype-ridden OSTs that fit the mood really, really well. It's by no means My Hero Academia when it comes OSTs, but it still does a fantastic job. The OSTs played at the end of the 2nd and 3rd episodes are absolutely fantastic and fit the series very well. At the same time, the opening does wonders with the series as it fits it so damn well! 


Character:

10/10


This is without a doubt the aspect that Tokyo Ghoul:re excels at. From the very beginning, it shows characters that you immediately care for. This season of Tokyo Ghoul:re centers around the Quinx squad, a squad of humans implanted with quinques that can basically be used as kagunes. As soon as they're introduced, they're so relatable. First, one sees Urie, who undergoes some of the most meaningful character development I have ever witnessed. Then, you have Saiko, who is a stuck up NEET that was forced to be a quinx. She is freaking hilarious and by far one of my favourite characters in the series. Another fantastic member of the quinx squad is Mutsuki, who much like Kaneki, shows such internal conflict and growth over the series. Lastly, we have Shirazu, who may be an idiot but like everyone else, grows tremendously and turns out to be one of the most loveable characters in the series. 


But wait, what about the MC? Haise Sasaki is without a doubt one of my favourite versions of the Tokyo Ghoul protagonist. His internal struggles are so profound that it really leaves me feeling so shocked by what he displays. He doesn't want to forget his "family" but at the same time, he feels like he can't leave things the way they are. Over the course of the series, Sasaki continues to be haunted by his former self and his interactions and response to that is what truly makes this series great.


Enjoyment:

9/10


Tokyo Ghoul:re does a good job at hyping things up and its foreshadowing is absolutely fantastic. However, it still rushes over things at times and that in on its own makes things a little worse. Overall, it is still a very solid and enjoyable series.


Overall

9/10


While this is definitely the best adaptation of the entire franchise, it still suffers from some pacing and material flaws. In the end, it is still a pretty damn solid psychological Seinen.

As a great TG fan, I personally think that this season starts off too slow, yet it skipped some parts from the manga. We already know that Sasaki is kaneki, with his personality built from the previous two seasons reset completely.
With only four episodes, it is still hard to tell whether this season of the anime will reach its maximum potential of the story from the manga (or they will make different story path as they did in the first two seasons),  but until now i could say that it is promising.
Studio pierrot definitely made the characters lively and enjoyable. Physical actions follow mainworld physics. I always like the kagune fights, they executed it well. 


The voice actors played their character precisely, especially Urie. The opening 'asphyxia' is good in its own way.


The characters are interesting, typically follows those in the manga. It is nice to see how the quinx squad interacts and doing missions together.


Let's just hope the anime will bring the same enjoyable moments like the manga, cause i love TG so much I don't want to be disappointed.


You guys hould watch it btw.

This season may be more controversial than root A, but it's not as bad as everyone says. Let me explain...
Tokyo Ghoul:re...where to start? Honestly I don't even know. I have a serious love-hate relationship with this one. I liked the overall action that was done here. All the battles were highly entertaining and very engaging. And I loved the fact that Haise was having a battle in his mind about his past and who he *really* is...but.
I really hate how horrible this anime was paced. It just felt so disorienting. From the start I was asking questions like "who's that," "where's kaneki," "why did helose his memories." Questions that a person like me (who hasn't read the manga) shouldn't be asking. They had a huge opportunity to make this a 24 episode season, combining this season with RE 2. But instead they decided to chop it right down the middle and half-ass everything, including the characters.


Now the characters are pretty entertaining...but, I still don't know who they really are or anything else other than they were assigned to kaneki as he is their "mentor." I *really* wanted to find out more about the Quinx Squad, but sadly we're never really given the option. The rest of the characters from the old cast were barely shown, other than Shuu-san, who I must admit, was the only one with a decent-enough back story explanation. But other than that, many things were either glossed over, or simply not explained. Like honestly, *spoiler alert* what happens to Hinami after she gets taken by the CCG? 


So, you're probably wondering if this anime is worth your time after that long rant. Well I have news, it kinda is. As much as this anime may have got hated on, there are some good things about it. For starters, it has a great OP! And, like I said earlier, it has some great action scenes, and has some interesting stuff going on with Kaneki. Also just to clear this up, not sure why people have said this so much, but the art style really isn't that bad. It's just not as good as the older seasons (a bit rushed, albeit still good).


Overall I would give this season a shot, specially if you're already a fan on the series...HOWEVER, I would leave all expectations and just watch for fun.

Why should you watch Tokyo Ghoul :re?
Story is Very Good (8). The question is... Did Tokyo Ghoul :re redeem the failure of its root a brother? I would say it did, but it could have been better. The reason for this statement is that, although :re did well with the story and presentation, it failed in its pacing. I have been reading the manga and it takes 3-4 chapters of the manga per episode. Please take note that each chapter of Sui Ishida's Magnum Opus is filled to the brim with details and character build up that would take time to fully adapt. So having3-4 chapters congested in a single anime episode is too much. In the case or :re, it ended up taking the story and character build up out of anime and focused more on the head on battles among doves, quinx and ghouls. Don't get me wrong, I love some good anime fights and some of the best I've seen was in this anime, but have not enough build up to back the battles up would end up in just a "generic" battle AMV style. This is what they should really try to work on the second season, even if it ends up as a patch to the mistakes of the previous Tokyo Ghoul anime. 


Art is Very Good (8). The difference is clear when you watch the original Tokyo Ghoul anime and it's :re counterpart. There was a huge bump in the budget this time and it shows on the details in the art per episode. It now has a refined feel to it which I really like. I would like this to be kept on the second season and polish it even further.


Sound is Very Good (8). If there is one thing that Tokyo Ghoul animation did right, it is on the sound department. Although not perfect, it captures how its universe should feel and presented through the sound. "asphyxia" by Cö shu Nie still continues the trend of and eerie vibe with the opening, and "HALF" by Ziyoou-vachi is just a perfect way to end each episode; a light, fun, yet pretentious wrapping up of the dread and darkness of the story.


Characters are Very Good (8). One of the strongest part of the story are its characters. However, if they are not presented right they would fall into the land of forgotten characters. After watching all 12 episodes of :re, I could only count the number of characters that I remember. Most of them are remembered either because I watched the original Tokyo Ghoul, or have read the manga. This is bad, and this is the product of fast pacing of the story. Its hard to invest in characters if you do not let build up and shine as the story progresses. 


All in all, Tokyo Ghoul :re is an amazing story that everyone should try. But I would still recommend that you read the manga, then watch the anime if you want to have a strong grasp of the characters and story. Or you watch the anime for the action packed Kagune and Quinque battles then go to the manga for details. Either way, you need both to fully enjoy Tokyo Ghoul.


With that said, I would give Tokyo Ghoul :re 8 Shirazu Kagune missiles out of 10.

Tokyo Ghoul:re is the sequel to the original Tokyo Ghoul manga and the anime fails on many fronts to capture what makes the manga great. 
Story- 3
The story introduces us to Quinx Squad, a group of half human/ half ghouls who work for the CCG to hunt down criminal ghouls. 
Having a squad of characters as the typical "main focus" is a nice change from the original series that had Kaneki as our MC. The problem here is that the squad never really gets any time for themselves to feel fleshed out. The source material here is rushed as it is made by none otherthan Studio Pierrot. There are too many plotlines at the start of :Re and it sure can make those watching it confused.


With all the info dump that the original source had, the anime sacrifices this in hopes that us the viewers can understand all that happens but it's just not enough. There are many new characters that are introduced and killed off easily, serving no purpose whatsoever. It's because of this that makes the show very hard to recommend, the multiple plot lines hurt it and does the show no favors since much content gets axed.


Animation- 3

Studio Pierrot rarely ever has any sort of show that can be said it has "good animation." Where the first two seasons of TG look ok at best, the production values of :Re are much much lower. From the first episode onward character models are very inconsistent. Much of the anime involves stills and the fights are as bland and cheap with no sort effort to be put in. 


Sound- 3

It's ok. OST of the show is nothing great, it does it job at complimenting certain scenes as it needs to. The OP "Asphyxia" by Cö shu Nie is pretty damn nice while ED "HALF" by Ziyoou-vachi is a decent but awkward closer given the content of the series.


Character- 3

Really the only likable new character for me was Saiko. She's just one of those "one dimensional" waifu bait characters. She's cute, lazy, likes to eat and play games. Everyone else besides her, Haise and Shuu are forgettable.


Enjoyment- 8

As horrid of an adaptation this may be i cant deny I liked it. It's hard for me to bash it since i love the original source so much but really the anime couldn't fully kill it. My enjoyment would be a 1000 times higher if it was a actual decent or even good adaptation.


Overall- 3

My personal enjoyment aside, this adaptation is a waste of time. Please do yourself a favor and read the manga. If you are looking for a good story and wonderful character development then you won't find it here as it doesn't exist. The second cour is slated in October and I highly doubt it'll be any better than this under Pierrot's supervision.

WARNING! POSSIBLE SPOILERS IN THE REVIEW!  
I will try my best to avoid any spoilers, but they are unavoidable at some parts. If you dont want to be spoiled with anything, please GO WATCH THE SHOW FIRST!
This review is solely based on the anime, i didnt read the manga, and im not planning to do anytime soon. So.. where do i start? Oh boy, it's hard indeed. Why? Because this show is just a big mess. First episode throws an audience into an ocean of confusion, not even trying to explain a single bit of what's actually happening, and why it's happening. I diddeduce everything pretty quickly, but i didnt like how it was done at all, just completely unnecesary. And with this magnificent start, we're moving to the actual plot.


STORY: 3/10


A few words: ALL. OVER. THE. PLACE. I was really confused what is the actual main plot there. It was bouncing from one to another all the time, without any real conclusion. Don't get me wrong, i like complex plots in my shows, but this one was made so badly i couldn't get hooked in any of it. Too many meaningless characters thrown just to fill the plot hole and make as much story compressed in 12 episodes as possible. Once again, i didnt read the manga, but i have a feeling, that the show should have twice as many episodes to make any sense at all, and hook you up in the story. The transitions in-between were not smooth, not even one bit. This makes you bored just after a few episodes, and there's nothing that can stop it. 


ART: 5/10 


A seriously big downgrade in the animation. Especially noticeable within the fighting scenes. I dont know why is that, considering it's the 3rd season already, just.. why? It feels clunky, not smooth and sometimes just ugly. Alot of some smaller studios can do a better work with not so big amount of money. I dont know who's to blame, but nevertheless, it's super average.


SOUND: 4/10


Tokyo Ghoul series always had some very good openings in my opinion. This one is still very solid, and i really enjoyed it (nothing beats the 1st season opening though, it was godlike). The ending is very forgettable, besides the first few seconds, where the riff starts. Its okay, but the rest, always skip. The same goes for the whole music in this show. Its super forgettable. I tried to pay attention for a few episodes, but it just didnt matter, i stopped and didnt even care about it later. Just some average stuff thrown in to play in the background, like it was done without any effort whatsoever.


CHARACTERS: 2/10


This is an abomination of a character design. This is the reason why this show is such a letdown for me. And im gonna be clear, i'll be VERY ANGRY on this part. 


The main character, Kaneki K... i mean, HAISE SASAKI. Dear god. We're back to the most average character design in the history of anime. Boring, naive, and of course always super nice and altruistic for NO FUCKING REASON. You thought that he was the worst in the 1st season? NOPE. This is way worse. It's like he's just a walking mannequin without any personality at all. 


Almost all the secondary characters dont matter at all, besides just a few in my opinion, and they're not even in the team with a main character. And im gonna be honest, i need to look at their names to describe them, because i just forgot most of them an hour after watching the show. That should say how forgettable everyone in this show is. 


Haise's team was also just the most average group of people you could imagine in an anime show, and the only kinda likable person was Ginshi. Kuki was the stereotypical type of a douchebag with power-hungry complex, and Tooru just a weaker link in the team, there always must be one, right? Right. Wait, there's one more.. yeah. Saiko. Just tell me please. Who is she? Why is she there? You wont know ANYTHING. She is just there for the 'comedic' purposes, being annoying and trying to be cute, and failing miserably in it, just to relieve some stress between some situations i suppose? There is nothing said about her IN THE ENTIRE FUCKING SHOW! She  just walks around, and complains, doing ABSOLUTELY NOTHING I SHIT YOU NOT. Ill never get why does she exist there.


Another problem with portraying anyone here is that there's VERY little story said about anyone. The most hilarious ways they do it here is when you're in the last episodes, and there is some memory retrospect section for about 30 seconds in the middle of a fight for a character that you dont care for, because they didnt say a single word about his life, feelings, desires, family. Just absolutely nothing. How am i supposed to feel any sympathy to anyone at this point? This is just a GIANT trainwreck of a character design. The only enjoyable characters were some of the Rose family, because there was some kind of a plot, and passion between the family and the servants. Not the best one, but it was pretty okay. And that's it. 


ENJOYMENT: 4/10


I have a feeling that this season had way more fights thrown in than the other ones. Im not a big fighting scene freak myself, i prefer the story-driven, character building anime shows, but i get that people enjoy some good action. Good action in this one isnt a good word to describe anything though. The clunky animation and the poorly made story was the nail to the coffin, and left this show without almost nothing to offer to me. I was bored and annoyed for the 3/4 of the show. 


OVERALL: 4/10 


I really wish this show was made well, but its just empty, lifeless and confusing. The combination of horrible character writing and the story that feels always unfinnished makes all of this a disaster. It is possible that it's made in a rush to squeeze in the manga in just 12 episodes for some reason, but i cant really tell. I would recommend this only to a die-hard Tokyo Ghoul fans, otherwise, dont waste your time. It's not worth it.

I have been reading the Tokyo ghoul:re manga since the beginning and, so far, I really enjoyed it, mostly because of the Tsukiyama Arc. Subsequently, my excitement with the adaptation announcement was expected, but, when the time came, the anime gave me a single impression: pathetic.
The disappointment began when the PV's were released, and here is where I start.
ART: 1
My eyes are still hurting from this stupid animation, it is exacly like those fan animations and I'm not even joking (I don't mean to offend anyone who does fan animations, it is only that I expected more than a beginner's work from a big studio).


STORY: 4

Once again, the problem with a Tokyo Ghoul adaptation is the small amount of episodes for a large number of chapters, but this time the solution was quite different and really worse. Honestly, I couldn't take anything seriously, because it all seemed so ridiculous. Even the parts in the manga that were precious to me and made me so emotional were completely laughable. Another thing is, if you hadn't read the manga, it's impossible to understand it. They put too much information in a short time.

I liked both opening and ending. At least this they made it right. Even so, the rest of the soundtrack was kind of "meh" and that one moment that Unravel started to play was very cringey. After all, I think the time was inappropriate and the song was put only to create emotion over a poorly executed scene.


CHARACTER: 3

I really like the Tokyo Ghoul:re characters, but, just like I said on the story part, you can't absorve it with such a rushed timeline. There's no real development whatsoever and the ones who only watched the anime can't remember anyone.


ENJOYMENT: 2

In a short explanation, it only made me angry and cringe a lot.


OVERALL: 2

When all these thing I talked about come together, it results in a big mess and I seriously can't see how anyone enjoyed it.

Tokyo Ghoul:re is what I expected but definitely not what I wanted.
A poorly adapted anime.
After Studio Pierrot decided to take the story into their own hands with the previous season Root A, fans were already disappointed. Tokyo Ghoul:re just adds to that disappointment.
Story : 5/10
TG:re occurs after a time skip of two years after the events of the raid on Anteiku. It features the investigator's side of the story, hoping to stress on the fact that there are losses on both sides of the war between the Ghouls and Humans. Unfortunately, the anime just doesn't add enough depth or assertion to the story. With alot of the backstories feeling repetitive, TG:re just reuses stuff from the original season, which was already sub-par when compared with the original work of Ishida Sui.


Art : 3/10


The art is despicable. I was hopeful when I watched the first episode, but it all went downhill from there. The studio hasn't yet realised that Tokyo Ghoul is not a generic shounen and should not be treated so. The fight scenes have no lustre to the point that all the action seems childish. There's generic shounen tropes like landing multiple hits at once, or that the seemingly harmless character is actually extremely powerful. Also, this is a series which should not be driven by action because the depth gets lost due to a change of focus.


Sound : 6/10


The opening, "asphyxia" by Cö shu Nie is amazing, almost as perfect a fit as "unravel" was for the first season. Chaotic music, all jumbled up, kind of highlights the messed up mental state of the protagonist. The ending, "HALF" by Ziyoou-vachi is also great which is a bit of a break from the general theme of the series showing some light-hearted moments of the members of the Chateau.

Apart from this, the anime offers nothing else. The music is not a focus during action, which just leads to awkward music-less fighting, and takes away any remaining feelings of enjoyment.

The producers reused "unravel" again, which could have had a great nostalgia effect if it was not almost completely muted when it played.

Moments where the OST reflects the setting of the episode are rare.


Character : 5/10


The anime doesn't give equal priorities to characters, with some just showing up when they're useful and then exiting for the rest of the episode.

The main characters aren't very well developed and even though it's been only six episodes, my hopes aren't high.

Sasaki Haise : Sasaki is the leader of the members of the chateau, who takes care of them and trains them in fighting. He himself was mentored by Arima Kishou and Mado Akira. The anime doesn't show any of his own ideology, or how he thinks. Rather, his main goal is projected to be to protect his mental state by keeping Kaneki suppressed. Character development is non existent.

Urie Kuki : Urie is perhaps the only character who really got some development. He is portrayed as a person with a superiority complex who deceives others just to get his way. He has potential, but let's his judgement get clouded by his envy for others.

Shirazu Ginshi : It feels like some details were just skipped upon and Shirazu hasn't just been developed as a character. So far he is just the side kick.

Mutsuki Tooru : I must say, Tooru is an extremely interesting and complex character in the manga. The anime doesn't give the same vibe.

Yonebayashi Saiko : So far her screentime has been limited, so no comments.


Enjoyment : 1/10

Mid-way between watching TG:re, I realised why I was so critical of everything. The main reason is that it's boring. The only agenda of the production seems to be merchandising by creating cool characters. In other words, making money. And it's garnering success because it's previous seasons were very successful anime. It does seem that everything is being rushed, with the production committee barely meeting deadlines which results in poor animation. I also don't have a lot of hopes for Tokyo Ghoul:re Season 2, which airs in October 2018. 


All in all, with skipped details and a lot less focus on the story than is required, it is barely a shadow of what the anime could have been.

I'm confused AF on how i have to rate this anime. 
The whole anime makes no sense at all, S2 & S3 are full of inconsistencies, but on the other side i know the S2 was out of the manga. 
If i had to take this S3 ALONE, like, i've read the manga until the S3 events, it's a good season, a bit dense but it still work, the characters are not that bad, and they still did a good happy end despite the atmosphere we had. 
BUT. If i have to rate the whole anime... that's probably one of the worst thing i've everwatch, the dead in S3 are not dead in S2 and vice versa, the war isn't the same.... There's litterally no scénario. \n
So, for the S3 alone, i would have put a 7/10, but for the whole anime it's clearly 1/10. \n
In all cases, i won't recommand TG anime. The manga maybe but this anime.... just run far away from it XD. \n
Sorry if my english wasn't rly good, i hope i was understandable. \n

Overall (5/10): If somehow Tokyo Ghoul:re is your first step into the TG anime world you are left with a convoluted story and series of confusing flashbacks. For those of you continuing from TG: Root, you will find yourself scratching your head as to how in the world you possibly got here.
Story (1/2): A time skip and confusing circumstances. Very little gets cleared up as the season goes on. More questions are raised than answers given.
There is an overall story arc but it really does not fit the TG world we got to know in the first two seasons. I don't like to compare animeto Manga or LN content but it almost seems like the producers just picked a random handful of scenes from the Manga and didn't consider continuity of the anime.


The action really picks up in the last few episodes but gives no answers to the story or the characters motives. Everything seems arbitrary.


Characters (1/2): You only see a few old characters and the new ones are very bland. Very little information is given making their story seem dull and boring. The only interesting characters do not stick around long. It does bring back a few characters from the OVA's, so thats cool.


The MC has an interesting inner struggle that we see him constantly battle with. It is done really well.


Animation (1.5/2): Quality animation, but fewer fight scenes. It did not look on par with the previous seasons.


Music/Voice (1.5/2): Great voice acting and suitably disturbing music that matches the series. The OP and ED were good.


Bonus/Other Points (0/2, nothing noticeable stands out): 

There is a surprising amount of LGBT/cross dressing/effeminate men content in this season.

While not being great, there are good moments, but a LOT of bad and dull moments.

This series is coasting on a solid first season and huge potential from the manga.

Seriously whats going on?

Watch this only if you like watching dumpster fires, otherwise drop it if you can.
Minor spoilers and complaining below, etc. etc.
--------------------------------------------
I was only watching this for OP Kaneki, which brings me to my first point:
The thing with the Tokyo Ghoul anime (to me) is that its true strengths lie in narrative situations where the show is undeniably shounen: the finale of season 1 works and gets people excited and riled up because it's the common shounen trope of the OP character rising from the ashes to take on a Big Bad Villain and defeat the crap out of him. It's an anime classic. The OP-ness,the fight choreography, the Unravel that played in the background to heighten the intensity of the scene, all worked together to create a rather "shounen" effect. And this can be tied back to the previous episodes in the season as well, where the fights and ghoul encounters followed a similar execution style. Tokyo Ghoul as an anime is unable to devote the level of time and detail to craft a story that will make you "feel things" based on themes and concepts alone; instead it relies on stereotypical action and suspense to capture people's attention, with the darker themes simply there as an added plus. And that's totally acceptable. 


But :re doesn't even have that much.


In fact, it was sort of gone already in season 2. I have this theory that there's a direct relationship between Tokyo Ghoul the anime's anticlimactic-ness and how sociopathic/angsty Kaneki is that season--which is ironic, because I don't think that was what the anime (or manga) originally intended. Hence, why it fails. There's a lot left unexplained throughout season 1, but it was never ambiguous or confusing to the point that it was bothersome. :re takes this ambiguity to an entirely different level, to the point where it feels like...the studio wasn't even trying anymore. With the Kaneki v. Jason fight, you can tell that they wanted it to be epic; they wanted viewers to get really into it, to freak over Kaneki's power-up, to worship his bad***ery. You can tell, even in season 2, when they lingered on Yoshimura's backstory, that they wanted to speak to something about human-ghoul relationships and the hardships he had to endure. 


Instead in :re, none of the action scenes made any logical sense. On top of that, we're introduced to, pretty much, an entirely new set of characters. Kaneki himself is totally new, hardly recognizable in appearance and personality, followed by a cast of negligible borderline-ghoul-doves or whatever. There's a lot of implied tragic backstory going on at first, an indication of a lot of trauma that the characters have experienced in the past--but, like, you can only foreshadow this for so long before I stop caring. Rather than exploring these past events in detail to develop our *central* characters--the ones with most screen time, mind you--the show inexplicably decides to spend multiple episodes uncovering the backstory and pre-re: events of a servant (?) of Tsukiyama Shuu, who was also easily one of the minor "main" characters in the previous two seasons. At the same time, it pummels us with *scraps* of details on Aogiri, other random character experiences pre-time skip, names of characters and places and events that we're apparently supposed to know and remember?, and a little too much focus on random CCG members who maybe had, like, a one-minute scene in prior seasons.


In the end, I was left wondering if the studio was even trying to get us to care at all.


And that's the biggest disappointment about this season. There are occasional glimpses of themes and messages that the story is trying to communicate, but none of it could be concretely pieced together in any way thanks to how the show is executed. The fights played out almost in slow-motion, and I found myself simply waiting for a minor character to die rather than leaning in and becoming emotionally invested in the action that unfolded. 95 percent of the time, it was because I just didn't know what was going on. It's sloppily done, and done in a way with little to no heart put into it. It's like this season was planned, and the writers/producers started working on it, and at the end of each episode they would throw their pencils down and lean back and look at each other and say, "Well, we tried." And shrug. And go home. It always seemed like my attention was constantly being pushed to focus on a multitude of possible plot points at once without any real reward in the end. This was why I said :re is incredibly anticlimactic.


So Tokyo Ghoul:re is missing a lot of things: interesting characters, direction that actually makes sense, good pacing, and OP Kaneki. It felt like a shell of its former self, an anime that had no heart and care put into it, a season that, to sum it all up, was very emotionally detached from its viewers and fans. It didn't seem to care, and so now, neither do I.


(Jk I'm still hanging onto the hope that OP Kaneki will make a reappearance which is why I'm watching the final season lol)


Final score: 4/10 for holding my attention long enough to finish all 12 episodes, some effort on the art/sound/animation, some effort to bring back the old days by playing Unravel in that one episode where Kaneki almost was OP and then wasn't, and Urie not being a total a** in the final episode.

As a Tokyo Ghoul fan, I was pretty disappointed when I watched Tokyo Ghoul RE. Adapting from the manga was alright, since it did not change any stories from it.
However, the animation was horrible. They did their best to make it look aesthetically pleasing, with great animation style. ( I actually kind of liked it). But it does not give any excuse for bad animation, where the action scenes were hardly moving. They were practically just pictures.
Also as for character, I could not get attached to this character name Haise sasaki. When I watched season 1 and 2, I liked Kaneki for who he wassince he was likable and had some kind of emotions. But Haise Sasaki is a bad character since he seems like he has no emotion what so ever. Even when he does it seems fake.\n\n
Overall, I did not enjoy this anime as much as I did for season 1 and 2. It would have been way better if the animation quality was higher and if there was more character development.

I normally don't write reviews, but since Tokyo ghoul has been one of my favorite Animes these last couple of years, I decided to write one. I have never read the manga, so can't base this review off of how great other people say it is. This review may contain spoilers:
Plot- 1/5
Haise is an amnesiac Kaneki. Now knowing all the trauma he went through during the first 2 seasons, you would expect more psychological trauma when he starts to regain his memories, but nope. He honestly sounds kinda whiny about not wanting to go back to being Kaneki even though he doesn't remember much abouthimself just that he use to be a ghoul named Kaneki. Other than that there's no plot I could ascertain. Maybe this would have been better as a movie.


Characters: 1/5


None of the characters, new or old are enjoyable. The old ones don't make many appearances and the new ones aren't interesting at all. One thing I hated about  this season, is that  they made the old characters bad. Like all characters that you wanted to know more about were lackluster and probably didn't need to be in this season. The only one I liked towards the end died, so...


Sound:0/5


The most disappointing thing in :re for me is the sound. I loved the previous ops and ends, but like the rest of the anime the sound is just bad. The most enjoyable part is when they played season one's opening during an episode. The music in the episodes at times to me sounded like a bad remix of the previous seasons sounds.


Art: 1/5


Average at best. Which may not seem bad, but other seasons were just beautiful to watch. There were scenes you would never forget. I just finish watching this and can't recall anything special during the 12 episodes.


Enjoyment: 1/5


One because only the last episode was even close to enjoyable. If you're very read the manga probably skip 1-10 and just watch the last 2.


Overall:


Just a huuugge disappointing overall. I binged the episodes, because if I had taken my time, I don't believe I would have completed it. I really liked the story they put forth during the first seasons that's why I finished it, so I'm really hoping next season is better. I scored it an emotional  5 because I know how good it could have been.

(SPOILERS AHEAD)
Prelim Note:
Wow, manga fans made this up to be great! I didn't read the manga at all but if this is what it's like, no thank you!
Thesis:

Tokyo Ghoul:re Anime Review
Episodes: 12
Genres: Horror, Supernatural, Psychological
Plot: 3.5/10
Most stories will have a clear problem in the beginning that the characters need to resolve before the book or show ends. Like in a classic mystery: someone dies, we need to figure out who killed them. Tokyo Ghoul:re doesn’t have something like that? We’re introduced to a mishmash of character who seem to not have any motivations, except one. Nothing happens that would indicate a problem until the anime is 3/4 over. The characters just live their lives, doing whatever they want, not achieving anything. The story is actually about how Haise deals with his lostmemories, but the way he deals with it is so incredibly unrealistic and boring. The show cannot even get its main objective done well. Also, can we talk about Deus Ex Machina? Maybe used once or twice in a show isn’t that bad, but multiple times in every episode? It’s so annoying when none of the characters can die because everyone apparently has magical powers of living. You finally think someone will die, nope saved by some random luck. It’s poor story writing when you rely on this cliché so heavily.\n\n
Art/Animation: 6/10\n
The animation is “meh” at best. There’s nothing really special about it. For a show heavily focused on fight scenes, said fight scenes weren’t animated to their full potential. Why this category gets a 6 however, is the art. I quite liked the character designs and seeing how old characters changed. Juuzou <3\n\n
Music: 5/10\n
Numerous times while watching this show I thought to myself, “You know, there may be something wrong with your show if the opening theme is the greatest thing about it”. The opening was great; everything else was lackluster. Nothing more to be said about it.\n\n
Characters: 1.5/10\n
This is my biggest problem with the show by far. None of the characters were likable, none (Juuzou is cool tho). The show tries it hardest to make you like the characters, except Urie, and feel for their struggles, but you just feel nothing. The show makes the ghouls out to be these harmless creatures that just need to eat, but you really couldn’t care less if any of them died. Speaking of Urie, he was the most annoying character I have ever had the misfortune of seeing in my entire life. His monologue was simply there to prove how much of a jerk he is and everything he does, everything is useless to the plot. He does nothing, but make himself look idiotic. Now, do the characters have any development? No. No they don’t. The one character that is meant to have a lot of development, Haise, is the most indecisive person I have ever seen. I don’t want to talk about the ending because of spoilers, but you cannot have a character develop when they are constantly fluttering back and forth on how to behave. His entire character is a mess.\n\n
Overall Score: 4/10

Tokyo ghoul:re is another adaptation in a series of disapointments. The way Ishida suis original work gets butchered is a sad thing to see since this is one of my favorite manga of all time. If you want an idea of how badly the pace of the show got hit, the first chapter of the manga was condensed to 5 minutes (3 if you exclude the opening) and not only do they cut scenes from the source material, the animation quality, soundtrack and overall direction of the show is noticeably worse than the previous seasons. Not only did they downgrade ALL of that, they cutthe details that make tokyo ghoul so interesting to read. 


I don't want to look like a manga only freak, because i truly believe that animation as a medium is just as good as if not better than the manga. It's such a shame that the adaptation just can't live up to the source material.

I really need to let my emotions out for this one.
I'm one of the biggest Tokyo Ghouls fans you'll probably ever meet. I waited 3 years for this adaptation. Nevertheless, my expectations were high because I was hyped for it 3 years ago. You can figure that I've read the manga too.
Here's my biggest issue with the anime.
It's confusing. I've spoken to a lot of people who are anime only be very confused about what is going on. "I thought Tsukiyama and Kaneki weren't that close?" "Who are these people?" And so on. Since I know the story form the back of my hand Ican easily follow along, but the story isn't some easily explainable and thoroughly linear work. I firmly believe you need to experience the manga in order to get full enjoyment from Tokyo Ghoul. With the specific style, foreshadowing, and narrative missing from the animation, the story is bland and frankly not as interesting. The panels were drawn in a specific way that makes their following animated direction seem awkward or lacking. However, no one I know will read the manga because they thought the anime was subpar. I agree. Unless I were that curious to see what would happen next I wouldn't be bothered to. I wouldn't be able to believe the manga is much better than the anime adaptations. Japan knew this would be an issue. They tried to send out ad campaigns telling watchers to read the original Tokyo Ghoul manga to understand the events a little more. This should not have been an issue in the first place, and it definitely contributed to why so many people are scoring this with such mediocre scores.The anime left out so many specific details, lines, and panels that I can't even begin to list them. 


I had to set all of my disagreements with the anime aside so I could still enjoy it. It's a good way to spend almost a half an hour of your time. Brutal honesty. I got to see some of my favorite characters and scenes animated at least. Not as impactful as I originally read them, but I was satisfied with seeing them at least.


I loved, loved the musical scores. I can listen to Asphyxia for hours on end. I really loved the ending too. The OST was pretty enjoyable as well. It was reminiscent to Root A, but the music was one of the good things about Root A in my eyes. It was refreshing.


The art was nice to look at. I thought the animation was stellar at most points, but it definitely had its choppy moments.


I gave Tokyo Ghoul:re an 7 because I love the original story and the art and music were great. The anime was cut short for 12 episodes and that can't be helped. The anime's story was lacking, which is why it got knocked down three numbers.


I really wish people would give the :re manga a chance. It really makes Mondays survivable. I know it's by far not for everyone, though.

Let me start this by saying that I've read :Re while it was still in its first few chapters, I stopped a while ago at around chapter 40 I think? But I don't remember being nearly as baffled when reading the manga like I was when watching this anime.
Everything is rushed, characters I remember loving in the manga feel so hollow and uninteresting, nothing makes sense. And once again, I'm saying this as someone who read the manga and just forgot what happened, because if there's one thing I do remember is that things made sense in the manga.
The art and animation is absolutely atrocious,the fact they even choose to skip most of the fight scenes to one character pinning down another without even showing how they got to that position proves how lazy they are.\n\n
Is this season better or worse than Root A? I'd say better, but that's not saying much considering how big of a mess Root A was. I love this series and it pains me to see it get such horrible adaptations. I have very low expectations for season 4.

I'll go ahead and review this. The first Tokyo Ghoul series was great. The sequel was pretty good, and enjoyable. This third one however is a complete mess so far. Most of the episodes of this installment are just one big battle played out over several episodes. But the battle makes no sense. :RE jumps around all over the place. Seemingly random stuff happens, and there's very little continuity of the story. It feels like you're in some random dream when random people just start doing random things, and nothing is explained why they are doing it, or who this or that new person is,and why are the acting that way? Why is this person upset? Why are they doing this?


That's what this show feels like. Like one long random series of random events.


What happened to Kaneki Ken? Why is he now some guy named Haise, fighting ghouls? Why can't he remember who he is? None of this makes any sense. 


Supposedly much more of this series makes sense if you read the manga, but for anime watchers, there's really no continuity of the story. If you left off on Season 2 of Ghoul and came into this, the effect is as if a huge chunk of the story has gone missing and you feel as though you've missed a lot of very important things, without them being explained from the time of the last anime, to this one.


Overall, it feels like this series has taken an interesting manga, and so badly executed it that it's worked out as a terrible mishmash of random events with huge holes in sections of the story and so much random chaos that you have no idea what's happening or why things are going the way they are or people doing things they're doing, that the overall feel is just one of confusion. 


There's lots of potential here, but overall, :Re fails.

Well what do i say? , well for starters It's like the budget for good animaton was eaten up by black clover and boruto and they gave mother fucking Tokyo ghoul ( one of the most popular manga ever written ) to the fucking interns ,Its not bad animation per say but for one it's a step down from the animaton of s1 and s2 which fit the shows dark and edgy tone and looked good for the most part  But s3's animaton is not fitting at all and looks like it belongs in a slice of life show , the plot does littlein terms of explanations as to what is happening and as a result leaves many anime only fans confused ( the original Tokyo ghoul manga made it fairly clear as to what happens to ken )  but nope not only do they retcon the horrible s2 they also didn't even bother to start of with the ken vs arima fight which was a highlight of the manga , I'm sure they'll show it down the line but its too late specialty as someone who's read the manga it's easy to see how many important things were left out by studio periot ,it also dosent help that the soundtrack is really boring and bland as a result Tokyo ghoul : re ends up as a  boring and bland adaptation that was so bad for me I dropped it after 2 episodes , but don't worry this is not an uniformed opinion I've kept my eyes on clips for the best scenes that I wanted to see animated but for the most part due to the off putting animaton made me feel that they didn't get justice , all in all personally they should have used the opportunity for re to let another more competent studio handle this beloved property cause as long as studio clown has it your better of readin the manga ( keep in mind this is the first review I've written on here , thanks for reading ^_^)

Tokyo Ghoul:re is an anime adaptation on the Tokyo Ghoul manga's sequel, Tokyo Ghoul:re. In case you do not know, this adaptation is going through, pretending the events of Tokyo Ghoul's second season did NOT happen.
TL;DR at the bottom (wtf, this isn't even long)
*If you have absolute NO intention in reading the source material or give a single shit about understanding the events going on in THIS season, ignore anything in brackets ()
Story & Characters:
The story of Tokyo Ghoul:re is well, insert description here, taking place 3 years later after the events of the manga Tokyo Ghoul. We are introduced with our main character, HaiseSasaki, a ghoul investigator part of the CCG as the mentor of the Quinx squad. 


In terms of the story, because the first half of the season are rushed into 12 episodes, the pacing is ridiculously fast, thus, the characterization, and minor details can't all be included. Not surprisingly enough, even the major details are skipped on, which I won't spoil as you will eventually find out if they are stitched in later on, probably not, (it's Studio Pierrot). Characters from the Quinx squad have backstories that are briefly touched upon and are handled poorly. I'll give credit where its due especially because it's a 12-EPISODE season that efforts are being made towards character development, such as Urie's backstory on his father, gives a good explanation for where his loosely-bonding personality comes from, his desire for credit, credit, and credit.


In comparison to the first two seasons, the Tokyo Ghoul:re anime's adaptation of the story is a big step up from its predecessor season, Tokyo Ghoul Root A, and a lot similar to the first season, (so far it is fairly faithful to the manga and brought this up a million times, the pacing is inevitable for a 12-episode season)


Art & Sound:


FOR a 12 episode season I THINK it's expected the animation should be PRETTY good. right? 


Starting this season off, you would think that they were at least saving the animation for the later episodes but as we get to the halfway mark, there is no sign of it. The shit animation isn't very noticeable but it's evident that they are incomplete. the art is pretty good, but how far are still frames going to get you? 


( art is probably the least of the problems Studio Pierrot faces when they fuck up their adaptations. had to add in my bias towards Studio Pierrot somewhere.)


Overall / Enjoyment / TL;DR:


IF you are an anime-only and are deciding on watching this...


(Read the manga, read the manga, and read the manga)  Do some research before starting the season as it doesn't follow the events of the season aired before it.


IF you are a manga reader and are deciding on watching this...


(Read the mang- why are you planning on watching this season? oh right because we don't have any other anime studio that won't censor the hell out of it. yeah fuck you wit studio)


IF you are COMPLETELY new to this series and are deciding on watching this...


it's clear you are interested in this series, (read the manga) you clever bastard, (spare some of your intellect for the dumb asses who chose to not to read the manga) before watching this season and if you are confused out of your ass, watch the first season, and do some research and/or read the original from start to finish or from roughly chapter 70..

SLIGHT SPOILERS! 
Not even the revival of the Nutcracker can save this franchise.
This anime has proven true that an anime can only be as good as its prequel if not for worse. Studio Pierrot has done a fine job at ruining what could have been a masterpiece in the cross-genre of action/horror. 
After leaving fans hanging for over 3 years with nothing but a disappointing sequel of √A to reminisce about, TG made a comeback with even worse arts and more cliché plotlines. Gone are the electric and vibrant palette which is now a somber and vapid backdrop. The MCs have become less psychological withSasaki looking like a bishounen in the role of a hero and always jumping out at the right moment to save the day. Stagnant interactions between characters and unsatisfactory horror scenes seem to wrap the show up nicely. 


Since Unravel, have we seen another "cool and catchy" song coming from TG? Fortunately, now we have. The opening song is sweet yet chilling at the same time and is extremely befitting TG. But it's not iconic. And don't get me started on that mistake of an ending song. I mean what on earth am I listening to Pierrot?


So if you're looking for the sequel to your fav anime, try the manga.

The story follows the synopsis seen here with Haise Sasaki being the focal point of the 2 part season.They basically took all the good parts of Tokyo Ghoul and shoved it down adrain. I haven't finished the manga but I can say so far that it is better than the anime. Not shaming Studio Pierrot but I would be so down for a Tokyo Ghoul: Brotherhood made by a different studio. Tokyo Ghoul:re is the first half of Season 3 in the three-part Tokyo Ghoul series.
This half of the season is, without doubt, a disappointment in many aspects.  From the first scene, the show jumps into action without bothering to provide background information about any of the new characters.  The episodes did not follow a strategic storyline and instead spread out in multiple, often nonsensical, directions.  While retaining a value of uniqueness, the plot was overly complex and decidedly underwhelming.  Thankfully, every episode had something of consequence; there were no noticeable fillers.
The art is a significant 'upgrade' from the kind found inTokyo Ghoul (S1) and Tokyo Ghoul √A (S2). 

 However, this is nothing special as many anime underwent a graphics upgrade in recent years.  While the art style fit the show, it's a far cry from the art found in the original series.  It also made it disconcerting having to reconcile with new looks for old characters.  That being said, the character designs were fresh and introduced new themes into the show.  All scenes, action and otherwise, were well-made and fluid.  The designing and production crews did not grant room for errors.


I watched the English SUB of this show and I'm pleased to report the sound quality is solid.  Every voice actor felt natural in their respective character roles.  The background music found across a variety of scenes was well-made.  The intro and outro music had an intriguing tone that I found enjoyable to listen to; I almost never skipped either.


Character development was monumental in this part of S3 - although not in the traditional way.  One of my prominent complaints of the first season of Tokyo Ghoul was the lack of personality development which led to stale characters.  In this half of S3, I can attest to the presence of significant change in many characters in the show.  While this may sound positive initially, there is a downside.  Almost none of the character development is viewable - it all happened before the show began.  The worst part is the viewer isn't told why some characters are behaving significantly differently than in S1.  Some aggressive characters were toned down and vice versa.  However, both the antagonists and protagonists had clear-cut goals and plans to achieve them.  The majority of the characters are unique and not easy to forget.


While Tokyo Ghoul:re has some factors in its favor - overall the show is a lackluster husk of what it should have been.  It did not capitalize on the storyline nor did it attempt to offer insight into the happenings behind the scenes.  As the audience, we're expected to just 'know things.'


I wasn't a huge fan of this half of S3.  It's not a terrible season half; nor is it a good one.  It's simply 'alright.'  After watching the original Tokyo Ghoul, I set a certain list of standards - most of which weren't met.  I'm hoping the latter half of S3 is better.

Short and sweet, this show took a serious nose-dive. Not sure if the manga is written better, but the way the story went is just infuriating to me.

Guess that's what happens when a character grows to be somewhat interesting in an Anime. Replace them with yet another cliche animu boi that stays in the safelane. So boring.\n\n
Do yourself a favor and save your time. I wish I could take back the hours this show stole from me.

this was a very average anime at best. 
Story - very mediocre, it's a bit of a hot mess, skipping over important details and the pacing of the plot is all over the place. The character's are made to be likeable and their characterisation comes across well, but a lot of things are left out and the plot can be quite confusing in places.

The way this story which was oozing with potential, has been released is just sad and heartbreaking. A manga that had the potential of being a true masterpiece has been adapted where potions of the story are cut out and important reveals are not even given much thought. Just thinking about the fact that they are releasing the sequel in October which is a 12 episode season and is the final season is truely disappointing and sad. 120 chapters in 12 episodes is madness, especially when it is a manga where detail matters most and so does almost every chapter. Either they will skip anarc or they will squeeze 10+ chapters into each episode. Both ways, i cannot find the "bright" side for this adaptation. Perriot and Perriot Plus have really let the community down with this. (Spoilers) 
I'm writing this as somone whose only watched the anime so bare that in mind cuz I think it's important for what I'm saying. 
So the biggest disappointment about this series is the story and how, as an anime only person, the story makes no fucking sense. The 2nd season(Root A) was a completely original series because they wanted to capitalise on the popularity of the original Manga but the Manga was not yet finished so the animation team made up there own story to fill the gap which is why the popular opinion is that it sucked. Skip forward to Tokyo Ghoul:Re andthey are back to the original Manga however a HUGE chunk of the story is now missing between the first season, the made up second season and now the third season. So your constantly left with the feeling of what the fuck is going on? Who are these people? Where have the original cast gone? They don't even try to explain this absence of continuity. Not even a summary. And people going 'read the Manga and you'll understand' is not an excuse.\n
What personally annoyed me the most was how the 'old cast' act around kaneki(Haise). So kaneki has forgotten who he was, Touka etc do turn up a couple times but they seem to have no will to remind kaneki of anything. For those who don't know, what actually happened in the Manga is that Arima won against kaneki and forcefully gave him amnesia. Something all his old buddies knew. So why on earth are none of them trying to get him back!? Why are they fine leaving him in the care of their enemies who are hunting them down?  Touka and kaneki were pretty much in love but does she want to help him get his old self back? Nah. Tsukiyama came pretty close to helping him but when Halse actually straight-up asks Tsukiyama to tell him what he used to be like, he bottles it and doesn't say anything. In sure thats to force a bit of drama or something but it's just unrealistic. \n
Im conclusion I guess I still enjoyed it, but the lapse in story(you HAVE to read the Manga to fully understand what's happening) and the stupid logic forced on to the original cast, ruined it a bit for me.

After watching the original 2 seasons of Tokyo Ghoul I had high expectations of Tokyo Ghoul Re. My expectations were not only too high, but it was actually so bad I feel like I wasted my time even watching it. There is so much fighting (probably 10 of the 12 episodes were solid fighting), so little explanation, and absolutely terrible character development. The best part of this season was the Opening lol. If you had watched Tokyo Ghoul and Re side by side it's almost hard to believe they're made by the same people. The only reason I give it 5/10 and not 1/10 isbecause I'm hoping they connect things together better for season 2. I haven't read the manga but I can only imagine it's miles better from what I've heard.

Tokyo Ghoul (anime) is a terrible adaptation in every way. Both this third part, like the other two. There's no way out, it's too bad.
The characters we met back there with the first part and the second √A were already badly developed. Twelve episodes (24, added) with fights played on screen, bad dialogues and in the background a beautiful soundtrack that really surprises and serves as a mask for the grotesque mistakes of the anime.
In RE, you may think that those characters will be developed ... But they will not be. They are again played on the screen and you need to figure out whatis going on, since nothing is explained within the adaptation. Worst of all, it's that in addition to these characters, they've obviously put a lot more characters inside RE ... And again, they do not know how to develop any of them. It's all done quickly, launched on screen in twelve episodes to end soon.


You do not understand the reason of the characters, the background of each of them. The real motivation does not exist in the anime.


But okay, I can not speak only negatively of the anime. Let's try to find some good points in the series. The soundtrack falls level, but would hardly exceed the first two parts (especially the first). And between the three parts, I have for myself that it was in RE that we had some really worthwhile sentimental scenes (like Shirazu on his deathbed) and Urie feeling the death of Shirazu next to Saiko and Tooru. The scene in which Touka sticks with Haise for the first time sounds clumsy if we stop to think but deep down, I felt truthful in the moment and in the encounter between the two. Seconds before, we see Yomo already looking at Haise. We remember good moments of the scenes in the previous parts of the anime. A little nostalgia? Perhaps.


The final scene of episode twelve, in which Tsukiyama is 'cornered' by some GGC extras, is not bad either. Especially when we look up from the building and we see Touka next to Yomo doing his part and avoiding an end to Tsukiyama.


Anyway, if we are to take into account (which would be right), the adaptation is very bad with these three parts released. It is well below average.


However, in every evaluation, we must carefully examine the whole context and this even serves an anime / manga.


We had all these changes in the staff and other 'adjustments' to adapt the anime and this corroborates not to leave a great adatapção. Tokyo Ghoul is an anime that suffered a lot with this and for certain issues ended up not having all its potential put into play.

I want to start this review by stating that this third season could have done anything and, it probably would have been better than Root A. 
Tokyo Ghoul:re takes place three years after the events of the second season. We still follow Ken Kaneki now known as Haise Sasaki and his "team" known as the quinx squad who are half ghouls that were humans turned to ghouls by the CCG. The two main arc of this season are the auction and rose arcs. In the auction the CCG bust a ghoul auction where humans are sold and, the rose arc centers around Shuu Tsukiyama. Auctionwas just an excuse to have over the top action sequences but, they were absolutely phenomenal, it also served as a reincarnation of the character of Takizawa who graduated from the Trevor Philips school of insanity also, his battle with Kaneki was phenomenal. I liked the battle between the nutcracker and, Shirazu who was by far the most interesting member of this team that we are supposed to root for. However the best arc presented on Tokyo Ghoul television was Rose, I absolutely loved how they handled the character of Tsukiyama, watching him go from the pompous prick to emotionally broken was something else. Also, Tsukiyama in my opinion was the most compelling character in this season because he had motivation and, development which can't be said for certain characters. 


The one constant with Tokyo Ghoul is its art. Characters design, action sequences and, locations were all beautifully animated. The ending theme to the show half became an ear worm after a while and, its upbeat tone was soothing after what the show had to offer. It was nice hearing unravel playing in an action sequence but, as much as I love that song they can't keep on reusing it. The opening song was completely forgettable but, the video package it had was really cool and, got me hyped for what was to come.


My biggest issue with the Tokyo Ghoul anime was the lack of character development. I understand that with only twelve episodes of content some stuff is going to be cut or altered but, it should not be at the expense of character growth. Lets start off with kanji/Haise from the start of the show towards the end it felt like I was watching generic anime protagonist number 26 on screen. This is a result of vital material being cut/saved the only time he seemed interesting was when he had the conflict inside himself as a matter of fact I felt that if an entire episode was dedicated to just Kaneki and, Haise talking it would have been pure gold. I love what the did with his hair fading from white to black as he recovered pieces of his memory and, at the very last episode he essentially became the Punisher. I didn't like him much this season but, I'm excited to see what comes next. His team is composed of Urie, Shirazu and, two forgettable clowns that probable have less than thirty minutes of screen time combined. Urie is that one guy who wants to take on the world, be the best and, constantly monologues and, makes you ask yourself how is this guy employed. Shirazu on the other hand was the most interesting member of this group, his manner, look and, backstory made him a fully flushed out character and, he was the one member of this team that I wanted to see have a big moment which he did. As stated earlier Shuu Tsukiyama was easily the best character on this season and, his crew was also really cool particularly Kanae. 


However, certain characters are completely ignored, Hide is not mention or seen at all this season aside from a missing poster, we don't know what happened to Amon although we did briefly seem him and, he apparently joined Aogiri. Aogiri (Hinami, Atayo, Takizawa, Eto) the had a moment in the sun with the auction arc and, a meeting where some inner turmoil is established but aside from that and, their appearance at the last episode they were a non factor on the show. The crew from Anteiku basically have glorified cameos. The CCG stuff was an absolute bore, I honestly lost count of how many meeting were held throughout the season. Also, with certain action sequences or story elements they don't go all the way with it which always irritates me. 


Overall, this season had its ups and, downs. Its was fun watching characters grow and, watching the story progress. Some action sequences and, story themes were brilliantly executed such as how obsession leads to depression and, how we have to embrace our inner demons to overcome adversity. It was beautifully animated and musical sore wasn't bad. However, the show leaves much to be desired, unfilled plot point carried from previous seasons and, a group of protagonists that I couldn't care less about even if I tried. 


To conclude I would recommend watching Tokyo Ghoul:re if you are looking for mindless fun to kill time and, the rose arc is definitely with your time but, to me this will probably be a one shot anime that I will rewatch certain scenes of when I'm bored. I recommend watching Parasyte if you are looking for a more compelling and, freakier anime.

I’m a huge fan of the manga series and I should say that this season might be one of the most faithful adaption we’ve seen so far. Still, I can’t really say I loved Tokyo Ghoul:re, like I loved the first season. This adaption seems to be lacking something, although I find it a bit hard to say what exactly. My best guess is that it just misses the atmosphere that came through so nicely in the manga.
In this season of Tokyo Ghoul, we meet Haise, a ghoul investigator who’s working very hard to keep together his little family. Just like everyone (except Haise) notices,he’s the former Kaneki and struggles with his other personality that just isn’t a sweet snowflake like Haise himself. A lot of people say they hate Haise, but I kinda like his sweet, innocent side (I do like Kaneki better though).


The story of Tokyo Ghoul:re follows the manga very closely, but just doesn’t seem to have the same effect. Maybe it’s because the animation is worse than ever before. Maybe it’s because the voice acting ruined some scenes (please stop the Japanese sounding German/French, why would you do that to my ears?) and made them almost hilarious, while that obviously wasn’t the intention. Maybe it’s because the story is rushed. Maybe it’s because there’s a big blank space after Tokyo Ghoul Root A. Maybe it’s because the finale didn’t really feel like something you would call a finale.


Some scenes in the manga made my cry. The same scenes in this anime just leave me gazing at the screen, thinking: what the hell am I even watching? Characters I had no problems with in the manga suddenly became very hollow, not convincing and sometimes even annoying, though I just can’t point out what has caused it.


Anyway, if the anime will continue to follow the manga, this might just be a necessary pain to go on to the better part of the series (and I really hope that it will turn out better than this season did, a girl can hope, can’t she?)
